metadata.description: This data was derived from "1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China". Based on Landsat MSS, TM and ETM remote sensing data, 1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China was compiled within three years by a remote sensing scientific and technological team of 19 research institutes affiliated to the Chinese Academy of Sciences, which was organized by the “Remote Sensing Macroinvestigation and Dynamic Research on the National Resources and Environment", one of the major application programs in Chinese Academy of Sciences during the "Eighth Five-year Plan". This data adopts a hierarchical land cover classification system, which divides the country into 6 first-class categories (cultivated land, forest land, grassland, water area, urban and rural areas, industrial and mining areas, residential land and unused land) and 31 second-class categories. This is the most accurate land use data product in our country at present. It has already played an important role in national land resources survey, hydrology and ecological research.

background: Land-use/cover change has become an event being of paramount importance to the study of global environmental change. Land-cover change is closely related to the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, i.e., the interaction between biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycle and sustainable exploitation of resources. The series of scientific study programs, issued and promoted by IGBP and IHDP in 1995, make the study of land-use and land-cover change (LUCC) become one of the hot topics in the global environmental change study. As a developing but booming country, China has formulated a series of policies exerting great influence on the land-use change. In addition, due to varied physical environments and vast land areas, its land-use changes not only influence the social and economic development but also impact the global change accordingly.
research objective: In this paper, the division of dynamic regionalization of land-use change is designed, for the sake of revealing the temporal and spatial features of land-use change and laying the foundation for the study of regional scale land-use changes. The paper exerts an effective effort on the integrated studies of “spatial pattern” and “temporal process” for land-use change to reveal the regional land-use change characteristics on the pattern of dynamic process and dynamic process of pattern.
challenges: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China. There also exist conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as showed in the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas.
dataset: The main data sources are Landsat TM digital images (520 scenes in 1995/1996 and 508 scenes in 1999/2000). Apart from that, the CBERS-1 (China-Brazil Earth Resources Satellite 1) data were also used to acquire land-use information for 1999/2000.
findings: There exists conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones. The rapid change of land-use change during 1995—2000 happened in North China, Loess Plateau—agricultural and pasturing interlaced area, Northeast China, southeast coastal region, middle and lower reaches of Yangtze River, eastern coastal region.

background: Land cover plays a significant role in Earth system science, which reflects the influence of human activities and environmental changes. Reliable and up-to-date land cover data are very important for land, ecological and hydrological modelling, carbon and water cycle study as well as global climatic change study. Many land use/cover maps at global, continental, and regional scales have been produced in recent years using remote sensing. These four global land cover maps are all derived from remote sensing data and created for the same fundamental purpose of providing improved land cover information for scientific studies and environmental monitoring, but they are different in mapping methods, data sources, and classification systems.
research objective: The objective of this paper is to evaluate the application of the four popular land cover maps over China land mass. The possibility of developing a new land cover map whose classification is compatible with a well-accepted legend system but whose accuracy is more reliable also motivates this study.
challenges: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. We conclude that the accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling. For the reference data, i.e. the 1:100 000 land cover map, the classification system needs to be transferred to a well-recognized one that has been used commonly in land surface modelling.
methods: We compare and evaluate four land cover datasets over China. So we first aggregated these maps by reclassifying them using a unified legend system. A large-scale, i.e. 1:100 000 land cover map of China was used as the reference data to validate the four maps.
dataset: The datasets include the Version 2 global land cover dataset of IGBP, MODIS land cover map 2001, a global land cover map produced by the University of Maryland, and the land cover map produced by the global land cover for the year 2000 (GLC 2000) project coordinated by the Global Vegetation Monitoring Unit of the European Commission Joint Research Centre. The large-scale (1:100 000) land use map of China in 2000, which was produced by Chinese Academy of Science to meet large-scale resource survey and land use mapping, was used as truth to validate the four land cover maps over China.
findings: The results show that the GLC2000 land cover map represents the highest accuracy. The MODIS land cover map ranks second for type area consistency and third for sub-fraction overall accuracy compared with reference data. The IGBP land cover map has good labelling accuracy, although it has a local labelling error and third consistency for type area. The labelling accuracy and type area consistency for the reference data of UMd land cover map is low.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that utilizes remote sensing technology to classify land use types in China?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that utilizes remote sensing technology is the Shaanxi Province 1:100,000 Land Use Dataset (2000), which is based on Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM remote sensing data. This dataset employs a hierarchical land cover classification system to categorize land into six primary types and 31 secondary types.

Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the difficulty in comparing different land cover datasets due to the use of varying classification systems. This issue was highlighted in the evaluation of four popular land cover maps over China, where the need to convert classification systems to a well-recognized one for land surface modeling was identified.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of a 'land-use/cover change' dataset in environmental studies?
Definition.Answer: Land-use/cover change datasets are crucial for studying global environmental changes as they are closely related to terrestrial surface material cycles, life-support processes, and the interaction between the biosphere and atmosphere. They help in understanding biodiversity, biogeochemical cycles, and the sustainable exploitation of resources.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in acquiring Landsat TM digital images compare to those used for CBERS-1 data in terms of their application for land-use information acquisition?
Comparison.Answer: Both Landsat TM and CBERS-1 data are utilized to acquire land-use information, but they may differ in terms of resolution, spectral bands, and temporal coverage, which could affect their application in accurately capturing land-use changes. The metadata suggests Landsat TM images are specifically used for the period 1995/1996 and 1999/2000, while CBERS-1 data is noted for 1999/2000.

Interpretation.Question: What can the use of remote sensing data tell us about the effectiveness of land cover classification systems in capturing diverse land-use changes?
Interpretation.Answer: Remote sensing data used in land cover classification systems, such as those derived from Landsat and CBERS-1, can provide insights into how accurately these systems represent diverse land-use changes. By comparing different classification systems, researchers can evaluate the reliability of land cover maps and assess their ability to capture temporal and spatial variations in land-use change across different regions.

Interpretation.Question: How can challenges in classification system compatibility impact the interpretation of land-use data across various datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Differences in classification systems among land cover datasets, such as those used by IGBP, MODIS, University of Maryland, and GLC 2000, can complicate the comparison and interpretation of land-use data. These challenges necessitate reclassification to a common legend system to ensure accurate comparisons and assessments, impacting the ability to derive consistent and reliable interpretations of land-use changes.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do regional variations in land-use changes have on the development of dynamic regionalization models?
Interpretation.Answer: Regional variations in land-use changes, particularly those observed in areas like North China, Loess Plateau, and southeast coastal regions, highlight the need for dynamic regionalization models that can account for these differences. Such models can reveal the temporal and spatial features of land-use change and provide a foundation for studying regional-scale dynamics, aiding in the understanding of land-use patterns and informing policy decisions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in comparing different land cover datasets over China, and how might these challenges affect the accuracy of land surface modelling?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in comparing different land cover datasets arise from the use of different classification systems by each map, which makes direct comparison difficult. This inconsistency can lead to inaccuracies in land surface modelling, as the classification system needs to be unified to improve reliability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be a conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, and how does this impact the understanding of dynamic zones?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Regional differentiation of land-use change in China could be caused by varied physical environments and different rates of development across regions. This differentiation impacts the understanding of dynamic zones by highlighting areas with rapid changes, which can inform targeted studies and policy interventions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion in China, and how do these conflicts manifest in land-use data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion are driven by the need for urban development at the expense of agricultural land. These conflicts manifest in land-use data as irrational conversions from arable land to built-up areas, indicating challenges in balancing development and resource conservation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using Landsat satellite data combined with CBERS-1 data for land-use information collection over a specific period?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of Landsat satellite data with CBERS-1 data allows for comprehensive land-use information collection, providing regional differentiation of land-use change and laying a foundation for creating dynamic zones. This approach can reveal rapid land-use changes in specific areas, such as North China and the Loess Plateau, during a given timeframe.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the diversity in classification systems among different land cover datasets affect their use in land surface modelling?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The diversity in classification systems poses challenges for direct comparisons and can lead to inaccuracies in land surface modelling. Reclassification using a unified legend system is necessary to ensure compatibility and improve the accuracy of these datasets for modelling purposes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objective does the division of dynamic regionalization of land-use change serve in the context of studying temporal and spatial features of land use?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to reveal the temporal and spatial features of land-use change, which lays the foundation for studying regional-scale land-use changes. This approach enables integrated studies of 'spatial pattern' and 'temporal process,' helping to understand the characteristics of regional land-use changes in terms of dynamic patterns and processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can a unified classification system be developed and employed to compare and evaluate different global land cover datasets effectively?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Developing a unified classification system involves reclassifying different land cover maps using a common legend system and validating these maps using a large-scale reference dataset, such as the 1:100 000 land cover map of China, to ensure consistency in evaluation.

Enablement.Question: What remote sensing technologies enable the collection of detailed land-use data in large-scale surveys?
Enablement.Answer: The use of satellite remote sensing technologies such as Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM enables detailed collection of land-use data in large-scale surveys by providing high-resolution imagery that can be used to classify and monitor land cover over extensive areas.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple remote sensing datasets enhance the accuracy of land cover classification over diverse geographical regions?
Enablement.Answer: Integrating multiple remote sensing datasets, such as Landsat TM and CBERS-1 data, enhances the accuracy of land cover classification by compensating for limitations of individual datasets and providing a more comprehensive view of land-use changes across diverse geographical regions.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to adapt classification systems for improved land cover mapping accuracy in land surface modeling?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the need to unify different classification systems used by various datasets and to transfer existing classification systems to a well-recognized one suitable for land surface modeling, as differences in classification can hinder comparison and validation of datasets.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when integrating global land cover maps with differing classification systems for use in regional land-use studies?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges include difficulty in comparison due to different classification systems, which affects the accuracy of the datasets for land surface modelling. There is a need to reclassify these maps using a unified legend system to make them compatible with reference data.

Expectation.Question: Why might the accuracy of land cover datasets not meet the requirements of land surface modelling, and what potential improvements could be explored?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracy may not meet requirements due to differences in classification systems and local labelling errors. Potential improvements could involve developing new land cover maps with compatible classification systems and higher accuracy, as well as reclassifying existing maps using a well-recognized legend system.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using remote sensing data, such as Landsat or CBERS-1, for capturing land-use changes over large geographic areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of remote sensing data like Landsat and CBERS-1 is considered effective for capturing land-use changes over large geographic areas. These datasets provide comprehensive coverage and have been instrumental in revealing regional land-use change characteristics. However, challenges such as classification system differences and accuracy issues in mapping methods need to be addressed to enhance reliability.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges when integrating various global land cover datasets, considering their differing classification systems and mapping methods?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of various global land cover datasets is challenging due to differing classification systems and mapping methods. This makes direct comparison difficult, and the accuracies of datasets may not meet the rigorous requirements needed for specific applications like land surface modeling. A unified legend system and improved classification accuracy are needed to overcome these challenges.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits and limitations of using a large-scale land use map as a reference for validating other land cover datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Using a large-scale land use map as a reference for validating other land cover datasets offers benefits such as providing a reliable standard for accuracy assessment. It helps identify discrepancies and validate the consistency of type areas in other datasets. However, converting its classification system to a widely recognized one can be challenging, and there might still be local labeling errors or inconsistencies in area representation.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how land cover data can be reliably mapped using different classification systems across various large-scale datasets.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets mentioned used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. The objective was to evaluate these datasets over China by reclassifying them using a unified legend system and validating them against a large-scale reference map.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the specific challenges faced when integrating satellite remote sensing data for land-use change studies in China.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as well as the regional differentiation of land-use change, which affect the integration of land-use data.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how the accuracy of different land cover datasets can meet the requirements of land surface modeling.
Assertion.Answer: The accuracies of the datasets were found lacking for the requirements of land surface modeling. The classification system of the reference data needs to be transferred to a well-recognized one commonly used in land surface modeling to improve accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential challenges in achieving a unified classification system for land cover datasets when integrating multiple data sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the use of different classification systems across datasets, which complicates direct comparison and integration. This discrepancy makes it difficult to harmonize datasets for applications such as land surface modelling, as noted in the content of relevant papers. A well-recognized classification system is needed for a more consistent comparison.
